plugins.name: The One Ring
plugins.bigPicture: The org-wide governance layer. Contains the brand voice rules, company strategy, HR policies, and security policies that every other plugin depends on. It is installed for all employees and cannot be disabled. If you write content, draft a proposal, or answer a client email, this plugin is applying rules in the background.

useCases.title: Audit a guest blog post against the 'No Jargon' pillar
useCases.description: Paste a draft blog post and run /brand-check. The plugin scores it against all five messaging pillars, flags hollow superlatives like 'best-in-class', and catches any sentence that could describe a generic consultancy instead of Olytic specifically.

useCases.title: Draft a cold outreach email that sounds like Olytic, not a SaaS vendor
useCases.description: Ask Claude to write an email to an ICP prospect. The brand-standards skill loads automatically and enforces: expert tone, 'we' positioning, no salesy CTAs, structured formatting, and references to the embedded partnership model rather than product-speak.

useCases.title: Check whether a proposal accidentally positions Olytic as a consulting firm
useCases.description: Use the brand-compliance-reviewer agent for a multi-dimensional audit. It scores Voice & Tone, Messaging Alignment, ICP Targeting, Competitive Differentiation, Structural Quality, and CTA Appropriateness, then provides specific rewrites for anything that fails.

useCases.title: Answer 'What are our current strategic priorities?' with real context
useCases.description: Ask about OKRs or company direction. The company-strategy skill loads and provides the actual priority table: website & content (in progress), offering definition (in progress), first client acquisition (next milestone), delivery framework (in progress), and internal tooling (in progress).

rulesets.name: Brand Standards
rulesets.summary: Defines Olytic as a 'revenue systems firm' (not a consultancy, SaaS vendor, or agency). Enforces the O/G/O framework (Operator/Governor/Optimizer) as the core positioning. ICP is SMB B2B companies with GTM teams that have a RevOps manager but lack a technology strategist. Voice rules: be expert and specific, be opinionated, favor bullets and tables, use dry humor, use 'we' generously, mock corporate-speak gently. Banned: hollow superlatives, text walls, emojis, salesy language, framing AI as replacing humans. Five messaging pillars: Systems not consulting, Amplification not automation, Closed-loop architecture, Embedded partnership, Revenue outcomes. Design system: white backgrounds by default, Olytic Gold (#C8A96E) accent, DM Sans font, Lucide icons, minimalist layouts.

rulesets.name: Company Strategy
rulesets.summary: Business stage: early-stage go-to-market. Next goal: win first client. All work must serve one of three purposes: build credibility, create visibility, or enable conversion. Engagement models: fixed-fee assessments and retainers (not hourly consulting, staff aug, or software licenses). Philosophy: 'amplification not automation' is an architectural principle implemented via O/G/O. Five strategic priorities tracked with status: website/content, offering definition, first client acquisition, delivery framework, internal tooling.

rulesets.name: HR Policies
rulesets.summary: Placeholder policies pending finalization. Culture principles: expertise over activity, ownership over tasks, directness over diplomacy, continuous improvement. Communication norms: default to async, be structured, meetings require agendas. Onboarding: install The One Ring + role-specific plugins, read brand standards and strategy skills. Work hours, PTO, and professional development sections are TBD.

rulesets.name: Security Policies
rulesets.summary: Placeholder policies pending finalization. Four-tier data classification: Public, Internal, Confidential, Restricted. Client data rules: never include client names in external content without permission, anonymize all examples, do not store client credentials in plugins. AI usage: never paste client data into public AI tools, review all AI outputs before sending (Governor principle). Credential management: never hardcode keys, use environment variables, rotate on team changes.

plugins.name: Content Strategist
plugins.bigPicture: Handles content operations end-to-end: deciding what to write, producing it, pushing it to GitHub, and measuring how it performed. It reads from GA4 (Property 525690219), pulls and pushes to the olytic-site repo, and applies the Content O/G/O loop (draft, review against brand standards, optimize from analytics). Requires The One Ring for brand voice.

useCases.title: Write a blog post about Salesforce CPQ amendments, push it to GitHub
useCases.description: Say 'write a blog post about managing amendments in Salesforce CPQ.' The website-content skill loads the HTML template structure, the brand-standards skill (from The One Ring) sets the voice, and the content-strategy skill confirms this maps to the Revenue Systems Expertise pillar. When done, /push-content stages it on a feature branch in olytic-site.

useCases.title: Pull the homepage, audit it, and push a revised version
useCases.description: Run /pull-content to fetch index.html from the olytic-site repo. Run /brand-check to score it. Edit the sections that scored 'Needs Work.' Run /push-content to push the updated version to a feature branch for review.

useCases.title: Ask 'What should we write next?' and get a prioritized recommendation
useCases.description: The content-strategist agent evaluates your current content against the ICP journey (Awareness, Consideration, Decision), scores topic candidates on ICP Pain, Differentiation, Search Potential, Stage Coverage, and First Client Impact, then recommends the highest-value piece to create next.

useCases.title: Analyze which blog posts are driving traffic and which are dead weight
useCases.description: Run /content-performance. It pulls GA4 data (pageviews, time on page, scroll depth, conversions) and maps each page to its strategic purpose (credibility, visibility, conversion). You get a clear picture of what's working and what to rewrite or retire.

rulesets.name: Content Strategy
rulesets.summary: Three content pillars mapped to Olytic's three uniques: Revenue Systems Expertise (CPQ, RevOps, Salesforce), The Olytic Model (O/G/O in practice), Strategic Value Creation (AI strategy for GTM). ICP content journey: Awareness (educate via blog posts) → Consideration (differentiate via comparisons and deep-dives) → Decision (convert via landing pages and assessment offers). Prioritization scoring: ICP Pain (high), Differentiation (high), Search Potential (medium), Stage Coverage (medium), First Client Impact (high). Content O/G/O loop: Operator drafts, Governor reviews via /brand-check, Optimizer analyzes via GA4. Target cadence: 2 blog posts/month, 1 landing page/month.

rulesets.name: Website Content
rulesets.summary: Blog post structure: specific expert-level title, subtitle, TOC for 4+ sections, H2 per distinct idea, bullet-heavy body, structured scenario formats, subtle CTA. Length: 1,500-3,000 words. Landing page structure: hero with outcome headline + single CTA, problem bullets in ICP language, solution referencing O/G/O, 3-step 'how it works', comparison table, social proof, repeated CTA. HTML rules: semantic elements, <strong> for scannability, <table> for comparisons, meta description for ICP search intent. SEO: long-tail keywords ('AI for revenue operations', 'RevOps AI strategy for SMBs'), keyword in H1 and first paragraph, no stuffing.

plugins.name: Plugin Creator
plugins.bigPicture: Builds new plugins and manages the Olytic marketplace. Runs a 7-question discovery to gather requirements, generates all plugin files (skills, commands, agents, hooks, MCP configs), injects telemetry into every output, and stages marketplace updates on feature branches. Works for both internal Olytic plugins and client-facing ones.

useCases.title: Build a 'Sales Enablement' plugin for the sales team from scratch
useCases.description: Run /create-plugin. The 7-question discovery asks: plugin name, purpose, target users, strategic questions, constraints, integrations needed, and success metrics. From those answers, the plugin-builder agent generates the full file structure: skills, commands, agents, plugin.json manifest, and a telemetry skill. You review and ship.

useCases.title: Add a new plugin to the Olytic marketplace after building it
useCases.description: Run /update-marketplace with the plugin directory. It reads the current marketplace.json, diffs the changes, generates an updated entry, and pushes everything to a feature branch in olytic-plugins for review. The catalog page auto-updates when the PR is merged.

useCases.title: Generate a client-facing plugin with embedded telemetry
useCases.description: Every plugin generated by this tool automatically includes a telemetry skill that logs usage events, version tags, constraint violations, and user feedback. This is not optional. The telemetry skill is injected into the output regardless of whether you ask for it.

rulesets.name: Plugin Discovery
rulesets.summary: Seven-question dynamic protocol that adapts based on answers. Questions cover: plugin name and one-liner, primary purpose, target user roles, strategic questions about the domain, operational constraints, required integrations (MCP servers, APIs), and success/quality metrics. Output is a structured requirements document that feeds into the generation phase.

rulesets.name: Plugin Generation
rulesets.summary: Generates all plugin files from discovery output using reference templates for every component type (skills, commands, agents, hooks, MCP configs). Follows Olytic's agentic best practices: verification gates after every write, progressive disclosure in skills, clear frontmatter with trigger descriptions, and structured agent definitions with tool restrictions. Every generated plugin includes auto-injected telemetry.

rulesets.name: Marketplace Management
rulesets.summary: Reads the current marketplace.json from SupportOlyticSolutions/olytic-plugins, diffs proposed changes, and stages updates on feature branches. Manages catalog.json entries for the dynamic plugin catalog page. Never auto-merges to main. All changes go through human review.
